newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Shell Australia's Clyde cracker to restart Nov 22.
newsitem.headline: Shell Australia's Clyde cracker to restart Nov 22.

text.p: The Shell Company of Australia Limited plans to restart its 5,500 tonnes-per-day (50,000 barrels-per-day) catalytic cracker after maintenance shutdown on November 22, a company spokeswomen said on Thursday.

'We did have plans to shut the catalytic cracking unit down in February 1997, but we brought this forward and have just completed the maintenance work," she said about the cracker at Shell's 80,000-bpd Clyde refinery in Sydney.

The spokeswomen said the three-week turnaround was brought forward as the unit was experiencing some problems and a decision was made to resolve the problem and carry out the maintenance at the same time.
A catalytic cracker is a secondary refining unit which breaks down heavy residual fuels into lighter distillates such as gasoline, jet fuel and diesel.
The spokeswomen also said with the shutdown carried forward, there werre no other planned maintenance shutdowns for any of Shell's Australian units in 1997.
Shell has a 115,000-bpd refinery in near Melbourne in New South Wales.
